postsData.name:
Deb Berman
Deb Berman
postsData.content:
What problem are you helping your customers fix? If you can't answer this question, you will not close the deal. Here is what the best salespeople I work with do:

1. They never talk about features (no one cares).

2. They don't use cute-sey product names (no one knows what they are or why they matter).

3. They are curious, they listen and they take time to formulate a high level, strategic solution to a complex problem.

4. They assume the sale and insert themselves into next steps. (For example instead of "what are the next steps" they say: "What I typically do is work with you to help Nancy from accounting understand the impact our partnership will have - does tomorrow at 2:00 work for the two of you?" They are specific and action oriented without assigning "homework" to prospects).

Stop talking about features (no one cares)... and lean in to solving problems and watch your deal velocity improve....
What did I miss?
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Focusing on problem-solving really transforms the sales conversation. Its all about building relationships and trust!

postsData.name:
Brian Sykes
Brian Sykes
postsData.content:
"Humiliation is a moment of humbling, narrated by the wrong person."

That statement was from a podcast my wife shared with me this morning.
Man. That hits you in the feels.

The sting of humiliation often comes not from the moment itself,
but from the narrative we allow others to write about the experience.

By others - I am even talking about the voices in our head.
Words that seem to be our own thoughts, but are just voices that spoke into our life - parents, teachers, adults, friends. Words that have become the narrative running in our heads.

Like a story told through the wrong lens, humiliation distorts our perception of growth, casting shadows where there should be light.

But what if we seized the pen and rewrote the narrative?

Consider this:
Every moment of humiliation - carries within it a seed of transformation.

When we strip away the judgment of others – and often, our own harsh self-judgment – what remains is simply a moment of humbling... and in that humbling lies tremendous power.

As Nelson Mandela once reflected,
"Do not judge me by my successes, judge me by how many times I fell down and got back up again."

Each time we rise from self-perceived failure, we demonstrate not weakness, but extraordinary resilience.

Like Kintsugi - the Japanese art of repairing broken pottery with gold, making the cracks part of the object's beauty, history and strngth - similarly, our moments of brokenness, when embraced and integrated, become golden seams of personal growth.

Maya Angelou stated:
"You may encounter many defeats, but you must not be defeated. In fact, it may be necessary to encounter the defeats, so you can know who you are, what you can rise from, how you can still come out of it."

The next time humiliation threatens to write your story, remember:
Stumbles are not your identity.

The true measure of character isn't in never falling, but in how we interpret and rise from those falls. After all, every moment of failure, is an invitation to grow stronger, wiser, and more compassionate. Failure is not final, rather it is a foundation of experience to build upon.



• Can you think of 1 experienced failure, that proved life changing when you realigned because of it?
postsData.commentAdded: This resonates deeply! Humiliation can be a powerful teacher. Embracing failure helps us grow and redefine our paths. ✨ #Resilience #GrowthMindset

postsData.name:
Drew Nelson
Drew Nelson
postsData.content:
How to Stand Out in 2025: Stop Sounding Like Every Other Salesperson

In 2025, buyers are more informed than ever. They’ve done their research, compared options, and heard the same tired pitches from countless salespeople.

The truth? Buyers are tuning out the noise. The days of manipulation, pressure tactics, and generic value props are long gone. If you’re still sounding like every other company prospecting your clients, you’re not just blending in—you’re getting ignored.

So, how do you stand out?

The key isn’t in having the flashiest pitch or the loudest message. It’s in the way you approach the conversation.

• Ask better questions: Instead of telling buyers why you’re different, ask them what’s holding them back from the results they want.
• Make it about them: Prospects don’t care about your company’s accolades—they care about solving their specific problems.
• Be curious, not pushy: When you approach the conversation with genuine curiosity, buyers open up. They feel heard, not sold to.

Standing out isn’t about being louder; it’s about being more relevant. When you shift the focus away from yourself and toward guiding your prospect, you build trust—and trust leads to action.

What are you seeing in buyer behavior this year? How are you adapting your approach to stand out in a crowded space? Let’s discuss.

comments.commentText:
Great insights!  In 2025, standing out is all about authenticity and relevance. Buyers are savvier than ever, and old-school "push and persuade" tactics are no longer effective.

Building trust through genuine curiosity and a problem-solving mindset sets top performers apart. I'm excited to see how sales continue to evolve in this buyer-first era!

What strategies are you finding most effective to stay relevant in this crowded space?

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Shifting the focus to the buyers needs is key. Genuine curiosity fosters trust and meaningful conversations. Great insights!

postsData.name:
Maggie Olson
Maggie Olson
postsData.content:
Thinking of becoming a Chief of Staff? 
 
Ask yourself these questions first; they may change your mind.

The CoS role isn’t for the faint of heart. If you are serious about taking the next steps into becoming a Chief of Staff, ask yourself these questions first;

 Do you love the spotlight?

If you thrive on being the center of attention, this role might not be for you. As a Chief of Staff, you’re often working behind the scenes, supporting others rather than being in the limelight.

 Do you thrive as the sole decision-maker?

The Chief of Staff role is all about supporting leadership and executing their vision strategically, not about having total control. If you prefer being the sole decision-maker, you may find this dynamic frustrating.

 Do you like networking and meeting new people?

The CoS needs to build relationships across teams, departments, and even external stakeholders. If networking feels draining or uncomfortable, this role might not play to your strengths.

 Do you prefer focusing on one thing at a time?

The CoS role is highly dynamic, with multiple tasks, priorities, and shifting challenges. If you prefer a deep focus on a single project or area, the broad nature of the role might feel overwhelming.

 Do you seek out issues to problem-solve?

Thinking critically and coming up with creative solutions for a wide range of issues is a major part of the Chief of Staff role. If you're more reactive than proactive, this job might not be a fit.

 Do you thrive on working solo?

As a CoS you work closely with leaders, teams, and other key stakeholders. If you prefer working independently without much collaboration, this role could feel overwhelming.

 Are you super organized, in your own way?

Organizational skills are crucial for managing multiple tasks, meetings, and initiatives. If you struggle with staying organized, it will be hard to keep everything running smoothly as a Chief of Staff.

 Do you try to avoid office politics?

Navigating office politics is often part of the CoS role. If you're not comfortable with navigating this dynamic the CoS role may not be for you.

 Do you dislike PowerPoint & presentations?

As a Chief of Staff, presentations and briefings are part of the job. If you dread creating slides or delivering presentations, the communication aspect of this role could become a major source of frustration.

So...

After answering these questions, are you ready to take action and begin your journey toward becoming a Chief of Staff?

Or is this role not for you?

**let us know in the comments.

 Share to help spread awareness of the Chief of Staff role.

 Followfor daily CoS & leadership insights.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! The CoS role truly demands a unique skill set—definitely worth reflecting on before diving in. Thanks for sharing!

postsData.name:
Danilo Miranda De La Espriella
Danilo Miranda De La Espriella
postsData.content:
Soy colombiano y vengo de una familia que, durante generaciones, ha trabajado incansablemente para llevar el fruto del agro colombiano a las mesas y hogares en diferentes países consumidores, especialmente en EEUU. Nuestra historia, al igual que la muchos colombianos es de una lucha constante, marcada por la perseverancia y el deseo de mostrar al mundo lo mejor de nuestro país.

He sido testigo de cómo los empresarios colombianos se han levantado cada día a enfrentar desafíos titánicos. Han trabajado bajo la sombra del narcotráfico, la violencia, el contrabando y una imagen internacional que, por mucho tiempo, nos puso en desventaja. A pesar de todo, nunca dejamos de soñar, de innovar y de luchar por construir un futuro mejor.

Permítanme darles dos ejemplos que cuentan la historia de nuestra resiliencia:

Hoy, Colombia es el mayor proveedor de flores para Estados Unidos, un negocio de 15 billones de usd en destino. De hecho, alrededor el 80% de las flores que adornan hogares, bodas y celebraciones en ese país provienen de fincas colombianas. Cada rosa, cada clavel, lleva consigo el esfuerzo de miles de colombianos que trabajan con dedicación.

Y, por supuesto, está nuestro café. No solo es uno de los más apetecidos y mejor pagados del mundo, sino que “Café de Colombia” se ha convertido en un símbolo nacional. Desde principios del siglo XX, los cafeteros colombianos trazaron un camino único, construyendo una estrategia de mercadeo que sigue siendo admirada en todo el mundo. A pesar de que Brasil es el mayor exportador, nosotros somos y seguiremos siendo el país cafetero. Porque no solo exportamos un producto, exportamos tradición, cultura y el sabor de nuestra tierra.

Estados Unidos no es solo nuestro mercado más grande; es el escenario donde hemos demostrado nuestra capacidad para competir con los mejores, construyendo ventajas competitivas únicas frente a otros países que incluso están más cerca geográficamente que nosotros. Perder lo que hemos logrado sería un golpe devastador, no solo para nuestra economía, sino para el legado de generaciones de colombianos que han trabajado incansablemente para llegar hasta aquí.

Es cierto que ayer domingo fue un día de mucha zozobra y lleno de incertidumbre. Pero algo ha quedado claro: los colombianos estamos cansados de la irresponsabilidad, de las promesas vacías y de los riesgos innecesarios.

Es hora de unirnos como nación, de proteger el fruto del trabajo de aquellos que, con esfuerzo y sacrificio, han hecho posible que hoy Colombia brille en el escenario global. No podemos permitir que nos arrebaten lo que tanto nos ha costado construir.

Colombia no es solo un país; es una historia de lucha, pasión y esperanza.

¡Vamos, Colombia! Y como siempre..

QUE VIVA EL AGRO COLOMBIANO CARAJO!!!
postsData.commentAdded: Inspiring words! Colombia’s resilience and dedication truly shine through. Let’s continue to showcase our rich culture and agriculture globally! 🌻💪 #OrgulloColombiano

postsData.name:
Shail Khiyara
Shail Khiyara
postsData.content:
𝗗𝗶𝗴𝗶𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗡𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘀𝗺 𝗶𝘀 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗥𝗲𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗔𝗜

Hoarding data, regulating platforms, and building walls around digital ecosystems to protect governments may not what one had hoped as an AI future. It’s a defensive play that prioritizes nationalism but comes at a cost: 𝗳𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝗴𝗶𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗱𝘀𝗰𝗮𝗽𝗲.

Nationalism can lead to isolation, while sovereignty at its best enables nations to make autonomous decisions while staying connected to global innovation. The challenge is: 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗱𝗼 𝘄𝗲 𝗯𝗮𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗻𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘁𝘀 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗼𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻?

Traces of 𝗱𝗶𝗴𝗶𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗻𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘀𝗺 are seen in Europe’s GDPR, which protects citizens' data but creates challenges for global companies navigating its strict localization requirements. Or take China’s “Great Firewall,” insulating its digital ecosystem while fostering domestic AI giants like Baidu and Alibaba. These are clear signs that 𝗱𝗶𝗴𝗶𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗻𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘀𝗺 𝗶𝘀 𝗮𝗹𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘆 𝗵𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗲𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴.

But here’s the challenge: 𝗶𝗳 𝗔𝗜 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗲𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗽𝗼𝘀𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝘀 𝗮𝗻 𝗜𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝗲𝘁-𝗹𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗹 𝗽𝗵𝗲𝗻𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗻𝗼𝗻, 𝘄𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗮𝗿𝗱𝘀?

The Internet thrives because of shared protocols like 𝗜𝗣 (𝗜𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝗲𝘁 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝘁𝗼𝗰𝗼𝗹) and 𝗪𝟯𝗖 𝘄𝗲𝗯 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗮𝗿𝗱𝘀. Medicine has frameworks like G𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗖𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗣𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗰𝗲 (𝗚𝗖𝗣) and 𝗪𝗛𝗢 𝗴𝘂𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 ensure global consistency. In telecommunications, systems like 𝗚𝗦𝗠. Shouldn’t AI follow a similar path?

► 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁’𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗰𝘁?

 𝗔𝗜 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀: Are your strategies prepared for a fragmented world where collaboration is harder and innovation must adapt to local ecosystems?
 𝗕𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗲𝘀: Fragmented systems increase costs, complexity, and regulatory challenges. Are you ready to navigate this shift?
 𝗘𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗘𝗹𝘀𝗲: A fragmented AI world impacts privacy, security, and access to innovation. AI isn’t just a technical issue—it’s a societal one.

► 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁’𝘀 𝗮𝘁 𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗸𝗲?
This isn’t just about geopolitics or technology—it’s about how we shape the future of innovation, trade, and opportunity. The question is simple: 𝗔𝗿𝗲 𝘄𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝘁𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲, 𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿?

If AI is to have an Internet-level impact, we need standards, collaboration, and a shared vision for the future.

AI is no longer just about technology; it’s about power, geopolitics, and the future of nations. 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁’𝘀 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘁𝗮𝗸𝗲—𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘀𝗺 𝗱𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘂𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿𝘄𝗮𝗿𝗱, 𝗼𝗿 𝗵𝗼𝗹𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘂𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸? Let’s discuss.
postsData.commentAdded: This is a critical conversation! Balancing nationalism with global collaboration in AI will be key to our shared future. Looking forward to your insights!
